dt: {bc}a brief remark or conversation {bc}something that a person says

dt.t: You can't believe a {it}word{/it} (of what) she says. [=you can't believe anything she says]

Could I {phrase}have a word with you{/phrase}? [=could I talk with you briefly?]

(Is there) Any {it}word{/it} on how they are?
If {it}word{/it} of this gets out, we're all in trouble.

There is still no {it}word{/it} from the hospital.
{phrase}Spread the word{/phrase} [=tell the others] that we're leaving in five minutes.
They {phrase}sent word{/phrase} [=sent a message] that they'd be late.
{phrase}Word has it{/phrase} [=I have heard] that the neighbors are moving next month.

I'll be there. I {phrase}give you my word{/phrase}. [=I promise]
You'd better {phrase}keep your word{/phrase}. [=keep your promise to do something]

{it}Words{/it} were exchanged [=people said angry things to each other] and a fight broke out.

dt: {bc}a remark that is made privately to someone

dt.t: May I {phrase}have a word in your ear{/phrase} [=may I speak to you privately] before you leave?

dt: used to say that you are about to give someone advice or a warning

dt.t: {it}A word to the wise{/it}: never sign a contract without reading it first.
We found this hotel {it}by word of mouth{/it}.
The show was a success {it}from the word go{/it}.
We were in trouble ({it}right{/it}) {it}from the word go{/it}.
Please put in a {it}good word{/it} for me [=say something good about me] when you talk to the boss.
({it}US, informal{/it}) I haven't seen you in ages! {phrase}What's the good word{/phrase}? [={it}how's it going?; how are you?{/it}]

dt: used to indicate that you are saying something by using only one word or by using as few words as possible

dt.t: Our answer, {it}in a word{/it}, is no.

dt: used to introduce a statement that repeats what has been said in a different and usually a simpler or more exact way

dt.t: {ldquo}She said the movie was a bit predictable.{rdquo} {ldquo}{it}In other words{/it}, she didn't like it.{rdquo}
So, {it}in other words{/it}, you're saying that you forgot to do it.

dt: {bc}in exactly those words or in exactly that way

dt.t: {ldquo}Did he say he wouldn't do it?{rdquo} {ldquo}{phrase}Not in so many words{/phrase}, but that was the impression I got.{rdquo}
We explained our views to the press {it}in words of one syllable{/it}.

dt: {bc}to suggest that someone said or meant something that he or she did not say or mean

dt.t: Don't {it}put words in my mouth{/it}. I wasn't defending his actions, despite what you may think.
When you want to leave (just) {it}say the word{/it}.

dros.drp: take the words right out of someone's mouth

dt: {bc}to say exactly what someone was thinking

dt.t: I agree! You {it}took the words right out of my mouth{/it}!

dt: {bc}the final thing said in an argument or a discussion

dt.t: Your mother's decision is {it}the final word{/it} on the matter.
Why do you always have to {phrase}have the last word{/phrase}? [=to be the last person to speak]

dt: {bc}the power to make a final decision

dt.t: The judge will have {it}the last word{/it} [={it}the final say{/it}] on the divorce agreement.

dt: {bc}the most modern or best one of its kind

dt.t: This is {it}the last word{/it} in wireless phones.
The van's design is {it}the last word{/it} in safety.
{it}My word{/it}, what a beautiful dress!

dt: {bc}an argument in which people or groups criticize and disagree with each other publicly and repeatedly for usually a long time

dt.t: Rival groups have engaged in a {it}war of words{/it} over the new law.
He gave the same speech {it}word for word{/it} [={it}verbatim{/it}] yesterday.

dt: Your {it}word of honor{/it} is your promise that you will do something, that something is true, etc.

dt.t: I give you my {it}word of honor{/it} that I will pay the money back.
